ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This is just about the only class I've taken where the instructor has not only finished the textbook (a full length textbook on Linear Algebra), but started a second, graduate-level textbook. If that doesn't give you a sense of the skills/insights you learn, here: you learn linear algebra.
Two textbooks worth of linear algebra
In-depth proof-based linear algebra. Abstract treatment of vector spaces, linear transformations, eigenvalues/eigenvectors, spectral theorems, multilinear/tensor algebra.

More rigorous introduction to linear algebra than Math 225 (we did the entire Axler textbook), followed by some more advanced topics, including tensor products/tensor algebra, symmetric algebra, exterior algebra, grassmannians.
Learned about linear algebra and tensor algebra
Basics of linear Algebra, and then more complicated stuff like generalized eigenspaces, tensor algebras, and symmetric and exterior algebras.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We covered a great breadth of material, and grading was relatively chill.

This was a very well-taught course. Yakov's lectures were clear and engaging, and he did a good job of making sure that we understood what was going on. I really liked the tensor stuff at the end, as well as learning about univeral properties. The PSETs successfully reinforced my learning of the material.

Strengths: I found the class quite engaging, and the homeworks + (take home) exams were very manageable. 

Weaknesses: For students already familiar with Axler's textbook (perhaps from a previous linear algebra course), a lot of the class might feel like review.
The course could use more regular homework assignments, but the lecturing is very clear.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely. Lectures are difficult enough where you always feel like the material you are learning is nontrivial. But problem sets are easy enough (while still helping to reinforce learning) that it doesn't feel like Kononov is trying to kill you. Take home exams are fantastic for the same reason.
Yes, I learned a lot of cool advanced topics in linear algebra such as Jordan normal form and tensors.

This course is well suited for students looking to refresh their linear algebra skills, without getting bogged down in matrix computations. We also briefly touched on some more advanced ideas (universal properties, projective spaces, k-algebras) which usually only appear in later math courses, so it is cool to see the connections and applications to other areas of math.
Yes, and Professor Kononov is great.
I would. Lot of good math in here. Linear Algebra is very useful, and it can never hurt to have a stronger understanding of it.
